titlestmt.author: Daniel Hartwig

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit

did.head: Overview
did.abstract: Master tapes of various productions by the Stanford Alumni Association including lecture series "Origins of Modern Society" and "Legacies and Visions of East Asian Culture;" Stanford University centennial symposia "The Human Genome Project" and "The Information Explosion;" individual titles such as TO TOUCH HISTORY: GORBACHEV AT STANFORD, QUIET RAGE: THE STANFORD PRISON STUDY with Philip Zimbardo, and STANFORD TODAY; and various conferences, meetings, and events.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

userestrict.head: Ownership & Copyright
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94304-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/pubserv/permissions.html.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Stanford Alumni Association Videorecordings (V0078). Department of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Collection
scopecontent.p: Master tapes of various productions by the Stanford Alumni Association including lecture series "Origins of Modern Society" and "Legacies and Visions of East Asian Culture;" Stanford University centennial symposia "The Human Genome Project" and "The Information Explosion;" individual titles such as TO TOUCH HISTORY: GORBACHEV AT STANFORD, QUIET RAGE: THE STANFORD PRISON STUDY with Philip Zimbardo, and STANFORD TODAY; and various conferences, meetings, and events.

Economics as History, Prof. Ezra Solomon (1143); Thomas Edison & the Nature of Modern Technology, Prof. Walter G. Vincenti (1146); The Origin of Modern Politics, Prof. Gabriel A. Almond (1145); The European View of America, Prof. J. Martin Evans (1152)

Nineteenth Century: the Triump and Crisis of Liberalism, Prof. Gordan A. Craig (1147); Descartes, Berkeley, Locke, and the New Way of Ideas, Prof. John Perry (1140); The Age of Reason and Enlightenment, Prof. Carolyn Lougee (1141); Music as a Mirror of Society, Prof. Leonard G. Ratner (1142)

The American View of Europe, Prof. David Kennedy (1151); The Experimental Novel in the Modern World, Prof. William M. Chace (1148); Russia and Europe, Prof. Terence Emmons (1150) The Novel as Art and Insight, Prof. Albert J. Guerard (1149)

The French Revolution, Prof. James Sheehan (1144); Greece: the Invention of Politics, Prof. Michael H. Jameson (1137); The Legacy of Rome, Prof. Antony Raubitschek (1138); The Renaissance and the Discovery of the Modern World, Prof. Lawrence V.Ryan (1139)

did.unittitle: Legacies & Visions of East Asian Cultures

scopecontent.p: New Wine in Old Bottles..., Prof. Albert Dien (1270); Confucianism: the Social as Sacred, Philip Ivanhoe (1271); Taoist Vision, Lee Yearly (1272); Chinese Literature: Popular..., Steven Van Zoeren (1273)

did.unittitle: Legacies & Visions of East Asian Cultures

scopecontent.p: Visions and Revisions of Past in Chinese Art, Richard Vinograd (1274); Leaders and Led: Rulers in China, Harold Kahn (1275); Reform and Reaction in Contemporary China, Nina Halpern (1276); Looking at Gender in Chinese Society, Janice Stockard (1277)

did.unittitle: Legacies & Visions of East Asian Cultures

scopecontent.p: Taiwan: The Other China, Thomas Metzger (1278); Core and Periphery: The Transformation..., Lyman Van Slyke (1279); 1000 Years of the Samurai, Jeffrey Maas (1280); Histories in Japan, James Ketelaar (1281)

did.unittitle: Legacies & Visions of East Asian Cultures

scopecontent.p: From Modelbook to Sketchbook, Melinda Takeuchi (1282); Nationalism and Ultra-Nationalism in Japan, Harumi Befu (1283); Japan's Literary Legacy, Makoto Ueda (1284) Japan: a Learning Society, Thomas Rohlen (1285); The Paradoxes of Japanese Capitalism, Daniel Okimoto (1286)

Cultural Survival as a Basic Human Right (1267); New California: Panel Discussion (1265); Native American Communities Panel Discussion (1264); Dilemmas of Development in Amazonia (part 1) (1266); Ethnicity and Environment in the Soviet Union Panel Discussion (1268)
January 20,1993 - David Brady (1328); February 1993 - Ed Zschau (1325); March 13, 1992 - Paul Saffo (1250); n.d. - James Whittaker on NAFTA (2052); July 30, 1992 - Condoleezza Rice (1291)

To Touch History: Gorbachev at Stanford (Protection Copy) (1201); Advisory Council Meeting January 24-25,1991, (Edited Promo) (3023); International Federation of University Women 1992 Conference (Copyright IFUW) (1290); Quiet Rage: The Stanford Prison Study with Philip Zimbardo (Mixed 4/92 Master) (4534); Executive Briefings Output (50 seconds) (6496)

Stanford Admissions "Stanford Today" (6105); Stanford at the Crossroads: Planning for the Future with President Donald Kennedy and Trustee George Hume, November 1991 (6168); Stanford Alumni Association "Overview Tape" (6255)

Ethnicity and Environment in the Soviet Union Panel Discussion (10044); Fate of the Forest Peoples Panel Discussion (10042); The Reurbanization of California (10041); Introduction: Native Americans (10040); Parks, Pasture and Peoples (10043)
